importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking a significant cultural and religious observance for over a billion people globally.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, honoring the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Diwali spans five days, typically falling between October and November, with the main celebration occurring on the third day.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major festival observed by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists, symbolizing the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil.
The festival is celebrated globally in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and other countries with large South Asian diasporas.

Diwali includes five days of observance: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali (Naraka Chaturdashi), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (Govardhan Puja), and Bhai Dooj, each with unique traditions and religious significance.

Cultural significance of Diwali includes home decoration with diyas and rangoli, family gatherings, feasting, gift exchange, and religious rituals such as Lakshmi Puja and worship of deities like Dhanvantari and Yamaraj.

Religious narratives vary: in Hinduism, Diwali marks the return of Rama and Sita, the defeat of Narakasura, or the banishment of demon king Bali; for Sikhs, it is Bandi Chhor Divas, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings; for Jains, it marks Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment; for some Buddhists, it marks Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism.
Diwali is increasingly celebrated by people of all faiths and cultures, transcending religious boundaries and becoming a global cultural symbol of hope, renewal, and community.
The festival marks the beginning of the new Hindu financial year, with businesses opening new accounts and engaging in economic activity.
Gambling games like teen patti are played during Diwali in some regions, rooted in a legend involving Shiva and Parvati playing dice.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the Festival of Lights, is celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists globally on October 20, 2025, symbolizing the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil. The festival spans five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras (buying gold and silver), Choti Diwali (Krishna defeats Narakasura), Diwali (worship of Lakshmi and family gatherings), Padwa (husband-wife bond and Govardhan Hill legend), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). Religious narratives vary by tradition—Hindus celebrate Rama and Sita’s return or Krishna’s victory; Sikhs mark the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings; Jains honor Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment; and some Buddhists note Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism. Though rooted in religious significance, Diwali has evolved into a cultural festival embraced by people of all faiths, featuring home decorations, firecrackers, feasting, and the beginning of the new Hindu financial year. Cultural traditions include gambling games like teen patti, linked to a Shiva-Parvati legend, and economic activities such as opening new business accounts.
